course.subject: COMP
course.name: Artificial Intelligence Ethics
course.description: Artificial intelligence (AI) is disrupting every sphere of our work and lives, bringing unprecedented risks to society. This introductory course surveys the explosive area of AI ethics, illuminating relevant AI concepts with no prior background needed. Fake news bots. AI driven social media displacing traditional journalism. Drone warfare. Elimination of traditional jobs. Privacy‐violating advertising. Monopolistic network effects. Biased AI decision/recognition algorithms. Deepfakes. Autonomous vehicles. Automated hedge fund trading. No area remains untouched. Policy think tanks, governments, and tech companies around the world have started paying serious attention to AI ethics. How will human civilization survive the rise of AI? What are the new rules? What are the ethical frameworks needed to avoid extinction? What are engineers’ and entrepreneurs’ ethical responsibilities?

reviews.author: holam
reviews.title: COMP1944
reviews.comment_content:
If you are year 1 student, you should ask your senior about prof Wu Dekai.

Think carefully before you enroll this course.

Previously, this course is 4000 level COMP course.

(1) email promotion to COMP students
(2) email promotion to business students

Finally he only got 1x students in that semester.

Okay now he conjures a better idea.
Make it a common core. Then there must be people to enroll.

reviews.author: toki
reviews.title: compiling the child of tomorrow™
reviews.comment_content:
Don't believe his syllabus list.

Here is what you will learn:
- How to argue with Dekai
- Dekai's book on AIs being your children
- How to review Dekai's TED talk
- How to bullshit to get participation
- How to use Dekai forum that we never actually used

Life changing experience:
His motto is "AIs are your children". I would like to thank Dekai for enlightening me, because Neuro-sama is now my wife.

Bonus: He teaches some actual ethics

=====

Usually the lectures will follow a formula.
1) Unscheduled Dekai rant on random topic
2) Watch Dekai's TED talk
While loop:
3) He asks us for our opinions, you raise your hand to speak out to the class.
4) Other classmates will respond to your comments, and the chain continues until Dekai doesn't like one of the takes and begins debating with that one student.

Judging off of purely the contents, the best parts of this course are the discussions we have. He brings up issues and we discuss. Wish we just skipped all the foreplay so we had time for longer and better discussions. But this part of the course which I liked isn't really sunshine and rainbows either (read Grading).
reviews.comment_teaching:
Dekai is legitimately a very active teacher. There is never any dead air like the other profs in UST and you won't be bored. He is the type of teacher who would explain everything in great detail.

Problem is he talks about things that are COMPLETELY UNRELATED to the "syllabus materials". He does not explain what AI means until mid semester, he does not introduce ethics terms until late semester. The first few weeks of the course consisted 30 mins of rants about the latest AI trends. The one I remember the most was on Elon Musk buying out Twitter. He dragged this on for so long because someone replied to him with a different POV. Isn't this a credit bearing course? We have a midterm right? Can we please get back to the planned contents?

Discussion is a very big part of the course. I did not talk too much when compared to the rest of the class. Some students are very active and I enjoy listening to their opinions. Dekai's comments, are very biased to (that particular side).

Small rant:
Dekai went for a "United Nations" meeting and we skipped 2 weeks of lessons, and he comes back telling us we need to come for lecture at 7:30AM. We thought it would be on Zoom, but NO you have to come back F2F, and remember, if you don't come back, no participation score, bad grade gg. (My friend lives on the other side of HK, he has to wake up at 5 for Dekai).

Also, there was one lesson where he just "decided" to not show up, I only had his lesson that day, what a waste of my bus fare and time.
reviews.comment_grading:
Participation, Quiz, Homework, Midterm, Final Project(Video)

I'm not rating it lower for grading just because it is very easy to rig the system to get yourself higher grading. Otherwise, the grading for this course is disgustingly unfair.

For the midterm, remember to study on the different ethics terms. if you pay enough attention during class, you would have learnt basic bullshitting skills, and you'll probably be fine finishing the midterm with good scores. If you have done DSE, the question type is similar to Liberal Studies data-based questions.

================
Examples:
Q1:   Fox News Article reporting on Facebook Whistleblower
- What the inherent biases seen in this report, and what are the consequences of reporting like this?

Q2:  Some researcher's thesis
- Why AI cannot do critical tasks such as judgement?

Q3:  Report on Google's ethical board not including African Americans
- Do you think representation is important in such companies' ethical boards? Argue based on either one: deontological, virtue ethics, consequentialist
================

For the final video, make sure you stand out. He never tells us what the marking rubric was, and I still to this day dunno how I did for my video.

Homework is very simple. Just need to read some articles and find biased arguments. (I still don't know how that directly relates to learning about AI ethics but ok).

Quizzes are not quizzes. They are questionnaires from Dekai about stuff like your decisions on the trolley problem. For one particular quiz, we had to watch a Netflix documentary at home, come back and take a quiz on the contents of the documentary. Some of us are poorL and don't have Netflix.

A large chunk of the course grade is class participation. This leads to very unfair grading. Here is why.

1) If you are not comfortable talking in front of the class, even if you have a lot you want to say, you will never get the chance to participate. Hence, bad grade gg.
2) If your reaction time is not above upper quartile, Dekai will forget that you have raised your hand and you will never get the chance to speak. Hence, bad grade gg.
3) If you raise your hand for too long, Dekai will forget that you raised your hand and you will never get the chance to speak. Hence, bad grade gg.
4) The class time is very short, if someone argues with Dekai for too long, everyone will lose their chance to participate, and you will never get the chance to speak. Hence, bad grade gg.

If you REALLY want to take this course, here are some tips:
A) Whatever you say does not matter, just raise your hand as soon as you have the chance.
To put into perspective:
- Well thought out argument: 1pt
- Repeating ideas: 1pt
- Water is wet argument: 1pt

B) If someone begins arguing with Dekai, don't wait for your turn and just jump in and argue with them. It helps with the discussion anyway to have more people talking. The best discussions we've had are always the ones with the whole class arguing, no regard for raising hand. Remember to say who you are before talking and you'll still get the pt.

C) Agreeing with Dekai will shorten the time you spend your turn, and will give your fellow classmates more chance to get their point. Also Dekai will have a good impression of you.

D) Remember to check if the TA recorded your mark last lecture correctly at the start of the lecture.

We've had pretty good discussions this semester, hearing my classmates' hot takes on topics like AI uprising definitely helped me gather better perspectives on these issues.

But sorry this is all credit bearing, and Dekai's grading system is rigged. Don't ruin your grade for some "good discussions".

Follow these suggestions and you'll survive.
reviews.comment_workload: Virtually no workload. Just remember to come to lecture every time. Participation is important.

reviews.author: ちきばん
reviews.title: Analysing tech news in this new CC (by a Yr1 lab mice)
reviews.comment_content:
Given that this was the first offering of this course as a CC, future offerings should be better with less news analysis, more concepts, and a textbook (he claimed that it'll be published in 2022).

Issues investigated with excess effort:
• Information disorder: The inability of algorithms to prevent the spread of misinformation and disinformation
• Unconscious bias, inductive bias and algorithmic bias
• Remarks: These investigations began in Week 2 and weren’t complete until Week 10 (6 weeks later than the schedule)! The professor attributed this to the spike of Facebook controversies during the semester.

Issues investigated with reasonable effort:
• Creative AIs
• Strong AIs

Issues investigated with insufficient effort:
• Artificial children
• Artificial gossips
• Prescriptive/descriptive and deontological/consequentialist/virtue ethics
• AIs and weapons

Kind of useful concepts (but made shallow effort to cover them): Trolley problem, Scissor statement

Case study: Current news (e.g. Covid vaccines, Facebook)
• A LOT OF COURSE HOURS (equivalent to 5-6 complete lectures) originally intended for lectures on important concepts were spent to discuss tech news (with the most emphasis on controversies of Facebook), a significant amount of which was irrelevant to AI ethics (e.g. TRUTH Social, Apple VS Epic, China's crackdown on how long kids can play mobile games per week, you name it)

Remarks: I use "investigated" above because the professor didn't come up with a takeaway message after the discussion in each lecture, and you have to come up with your own.

The course description did say, "This course critically surveys AI ethics ..." The course greatly achieved the intended learning outcomes on analysis of AI ethics, but failed to achieve the rest (comparison of existing AI ethics frameworks, propose designs for an ethically aligned system, ...).
reviews.comment_teaching:
Enrolled in the course without reading reviews about this course to find out that the professor is somewhat biased (despite teaching you what is unconscious bias). He tries to persuade you to think that
• the media is biased against vaccines; and
• MAMAA (except Microsoft) are evil and untrustworthy.

Lectures mostly involved discussion on ethical issues related to AI and analysis of recent news. Very few concepts that aid analysis were taught. There wasn't enough evidence to rate how he 'taught', but if you take part in the discussions during the lessons, he can inspire you to investigate the problem from a deeper perspective. Oh, and classes often overran.

P.S. To those who read the reviews of COMP4901M (the former code of this course) and COMP4221, the professor is finally willing to share his slides to everyone after the class!

- - - - -

TA: Serkan Kumyol
The TA’s English couldn’t be understood by at least half of the class. And he gives vague instructions on assignments that may change in the last minute...
reviews.comment_grading:
Absolute grading
• ≥85% = A range
• ≥75% = B range
• ≥65% = C range
• ≥55% = D range

Participation score (25% of course grade): Backfired!
• Some students are so keen to earn these points that the professor often struggles to move on to the next topic, has to decide a cutoff for maximum participation scores, and award the extra points students earned as bonuses (with lower weighting).
• If you don’t think you can think fast and vast enough in class, rely on posting your views on the online forum to earn the scores (there’s a catch - you can only get a point if the professor thinks your comment is good enough). Expect a lower weighting though.

In-class exercises (20%)
Group assignments (20%)
Mid-term exam (10%)
Final group presentation (25%)
See Workload for the details of the above items.

My grades: The grades in the above components weren't announced (except the participation score). I got a median participation score, received decent verbal feedback right after the final presentation, and eventually got a B. Given the competitive nature in class, as a Year 1 student, I'm satisfied with it.
reviews.comment_workload:
Forum participation: You probably need to spend at least 10 minutes on each comment on the forum to ensure that it’s decent enough to secure your score. Some students set the bar really high though.

Readings (most of them are news articles discussed in lectures): Very light if you don't read them. Almost all of them weren't used in the lectures except the one that introduce them, despite being "required readings"… Some are really inspiring and worth reading though.

In-class exercises: Just fill in the Google forms (only 2 in this semester) that he asked you to. They're simple to complete.

Group assignments: Light. Create a mind map on Covid vaccines memes (and news) and revise it around once per month. The only task in which you may struggle is following the format.

Mid-term exam: Write as many short essays (12 to choose from, some have higher scores than others) as you can. Each one is hard enough. Worse still, some are on topics that aren’t even discussed in the class, so there's no way to prepare for them except reading a lot…

Final group presentation: Medium. Convert some nodes on your mind map into HTML NEWS ARTICLES (1-2 each) and do a 5-minute presentation on all of them in class. Lighter if you know how to write HTML documents natively.

reviews.author: ltxtftrsn
reviews.comment_content:
Had a good content structure, but foreshadowing, "had". For the first few lessons, Professor did stick to the content structure, and the content was good and clear on basic concepts on cognitive biases. The rest of the semester is practically talking about the very same topic of Facebook algorithm issues (news at the time, but mostly only barely related to the course topic and keeps going off track).
Going off track wasn't precisely the worst part, it was that when assignments are put aside and forgotten for weeks just to talk about recent and not exactly directly related to the course contents.
And as a kind reminder, topics often get rather political.
reviews.comment_teaching: As said in the content section, the Professor keeps going off track; teachings are made fairly boring and classes usually only evolve into multiple "discussions" between the Professor and several active students. Also, the Professor always says things that are not understandable or seemingly have logical flaws.
reviews.comment_grading:
Quite a large portion of the grades are related to on-lecture and on-forum discussions (practically, participation scores). As time passes by, people either speak A LOT or barely anything. So, while attendance was not compulsory, it practically affects 35% of your score.
There was a very late mid-term exam, which was practically more things to write than in the HKDSE Liberal Studies papers. An hour for 10 open-ended essay-type questions.
reviews.comment_workload:
Fair workload, around one assignment per week or two which are group projects.
There's also an end-sem project which is a presentation of the group assignments, which was quite a hurry coz of delays in teaching.

reviews.author: Ian123
reviews.comment_content: This course discusses the ethics of AI. A short discussion of a recent news article will be at the beginning of the class. Students are encouraged to express their views and opinions on recent events in the tech industry. This course surrounds topics such as types of biases, the trolley problem, and how machine learning training data sets introduced errors in AI.
reviews.comment_grading: The midterm is relatively easy as it only required students to identify types of biases in the article and evaluate the underlying issues that the news article is trying to present. Participation in class and in the online discussion forum is also important if you want a decent grade.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload was little in this course, there was a midterm exam and a group presentation.

reviews.author: iamahuman
reviews.comment_content: Although there is a website (http://home.cse.ust.hk/~dekai/1944/ ) telling you what will be taught in each lesson, it is useless. The order of content being taught will change according to the latest news.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Every lesson, he would share lots of latest news and talk about his view. Then, he will invite someone to share theirs, which is part of the grading.

Sometimes when he runs out of news or realize that some of the content have not be taught, he will use the PowerPoint prepared to talk about.
reviews.comment_grading:
Class participation ~25%
In-class exercises/quizzes ~20%
Assignments ~20%
Midterm exam ~10%
Final presentation ~25%

Above is the grade weighting posted on the website. But it seems to be useless. During the lesson, we seldom have exercises and quizzes. Also, none of the mark will be given to you so you cannot know how you perform previously. And for class participation, there are no standard telling you how many percentage you can get.

The midterm exam is very late because he doesn't know to affect other examination (Although I think it is just because he is far behind schedule). Because it is the first time of the course, he makes the exam too lengthy. Ten questions with most of them are needed to read a news and answer question but time limit is only around 60 minutes.
reviews.comment_workload: Workload is very light. Although there is three assignments, they are both based on one mind map. So the only thing you need to do in the course is just a mind map, some surveys through google form, and a 5-minute group presentation based on that mind map.

reviews.author: Peterson
reviews.title: Not as bad as people say
reviews.comment_content: The problems with the use and design of AI, through various news and social events to illustrate the concepts taught in lessons. It also contains certain biases on how people think when it comes to decision making (like psychology), and how that contributes to the flaws of current AI designs.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor is slightly biased when it comes to news analysis, but that is the way he usually illustrates the concepts, and if you disagree with his views, he will ask you more questions, which is quite disrespectful. He started the course well with a test on human psychology, but then he did not stick to the syllabus and just analyze news all lesson. He was so afraid we fail midterm because he didn't teach well, he gave us notes summary the lesson before the midterm.
reviews.comment_grading:
Actually, I think the grading is more lenient/amended, I got no participation and in-class marks and still got B range. But he said 85%+ is A and 75%+ is B.

And the TA keeps changing the requirements to the assignment.

Class participation (type bullshit on online forum and ask and answer questions in lectures): 25%

Midterm (essay writing, more intense than LS exam but questions are similar to that. But open notes and internet): 10%

Assignments(draw a mind map of what you learned with groupmates):20%

In-class exercises/quizzes(I haven't done any):20%

Final presentation(write an news article and have 5 minute group presentation):20%
reviews.comment_workload: Not heavy workload, the news article does not have to be long, just state facts, and then present to class. Everyone just need to speak for roughly one minute, so not much to do.

reviews.author: halooo
reviews.title: Participation/ discussion/ debate based course with simple assignments
reviews.comment_content:
AI ethics concepts, see content page

http://home.cse.ust.hk/~dekai/1944/
reviews.comment_teaching:
Each week we cover a different aspect of AI ethics and society, with the class structured in two halves.

The first half begins with a short provocation such as a TED talk, to create a controversial context for discussion and debate. We then review the relevant literature, illuminate major concepts, and critique them. The first half finishes with a questionnaire/quiz that tests your understanding and poses self-reflection challenges.

The second half exercises these concepts. We may do case studies, breakout groups, collaborative mind mapping, and other interactive work to help concretize, explore, and internalize the issues and challenges. Individual contributions to these exercises over the course of the semester are a large part of the assessment for the course.

Provocative content,
Discussion-based
reviews.comment_grading:
Virtually 45% from in class participation, which is counted for every point you raised in class or on the online forum

Your grade will be determined by a combination of factors:

Grade weighting
Class participation ~25%
In-class exercises/quizzes ~20%
Assignments ~20%
Midterm exam ~10%
Final presentation ~25%
reviews.comment_workload:
Very low,
Assignment 1: News content map
2: one midterm mid-length written question based questions
3: final presentation of the news content map
